headline.main: Two Months After the Attack, a Veterans Day Parade During Wartime

lead_paragraph: In recent years, the march up Fifth Avenue for New York's annual Veterans Day Parade was often a lonely one, but yesterday the men and women who dusted off their old uniforms, donned Veterans of Foreign Wars hats and pinned on decades-old medals found their reception transformed by the attack that shook the city two months ago. Gift shops sold ''America United'' T-shirts. American flags were taped up in pharmacies and office windows. Starbucks flew the colors. And if the crowd still fell far short of even a rained-on Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, there was still a steady stream of people cheering on the veterans, waving flags and signs and wearing the red-white-and-blue pins and ribbons that have become everyday accessories for many.
abstract: New York's Veterans Day parade attracts throngs of onlookers cheering veterans as memories of terror attack on World Trade Center are fresh and fighting continues in Afghanistan; photo (M)
